0.text: Our company has a new strategic initiative to increase market penetration, maximise brand loyalty, and enhance intangible assets.

8.text: In pursuit of these objectives, we've started a new project --

11.text: for which we require 7 red lines.

14.text: I understand your company can help us in this matter.

17.text: Walter here will be the Project Manager. Walter, we can do this, can't we?

23.text: Anderson here is our expert in all matters related to drawing red lines.

26.text: We brought him along today to share his professional opinion.

30.text: Nice to meet you! Well, you all know me.

32.text: This is Justine, our company's design specialist.

36.text: We need you to draw seven red lines.

39.text: All of them strictly perpendicular; some with green ink and some with transparent. Can you do that?

47.text: Let's not rush into any hasty answers, Anderson! The task has been set and needs to be carried out.

51.text: At the end of the day, you are an expert.

53.text: The term "red line" implies the colour of the line to be red. To draw a red line with green ink is --

58.text: well if it is not exactly impossible, then it is pretty close to being impossible.

64.text: I mean, it is quite possible that there are some people, say suffering from colour blindness,

68.text: for whom the colour of the lines doesn't really make a difference.

70.text: But I am quite sure that the target audience of your project does not consists solely of such people.

75.text: So in principle this is possible.

81.text: A line as such can be drawn with absolutely any ink.

84.text: But if you want to get a red line, you need to use red ink.

88.text: What if we draw them with blue ink?

90.text: It still won't work. If you use blue ink, you will get blue lines.

97.text: And what exactly did you mean, when you talked about the transparent ink?

102.text: I'm sure you know what "transparent" means?

105.text: And what a "red line" means, I hope I don't need to explain to you?

110.text: Well... You need to draw red lines with transparent ink.

115.text: Could you describe what you imagine the end result would look like?

118.text: C'mon, Anderson! What do we have here, kindergarten?

121.text: Let's not waste our time with these unproductive quarrels.

125.text: The task has been set; the task is plain and clear.

127.text: Now, if you have any specific questions, go ahead!

133.text: Alright, let's leave aside the colour for the moment.

136.text: You had something there also relating to perpendicularity?..

150.text: I assumed you know what perpendicular lines are like!

152.text: Of course he does. He's an expert!

156.text: All seven can't be simultaneously perpendicular to each other.

169.text: And another one. Is it perpendicular to the first line?

180.text: Wait, wait, I'm not done. And a third one: is it perpendicular to the first line?

186.text: Yes, it is! But it doesn't cross the second line. They're both parallel.

197.text: There it is. Two lines can be perpendicular --

233.text: And there are three, not seven.

238.text: Indeed. Wanted to ask that myself.

241.text: I have a blue pen with me. This was just a demonstration --

244.text: That's the problem, your lines are blue. Draw them with red ink!

249.text: How do you know before you've tried?

250.text: Lets draw them with red ink and then let's see.

252.text: I don't have a red pen with me, --

253.text: but I am completely certain that with red ink the result will still be the same.

259.text: Didn't you tell us earlier that you can only draw red lines with red ink?

262.text: In fact, yes, I've written it down here!

264.text: And now you want to draw them with a blue ink. Do you want to call these red lines?

269.text: I think I understand. You're not talking about the colour now, right?

273.text: You're talking about that, what do you call it: per-per, dick-dick --

278.text: That's it, now you've confused everyone.

281.text: So what exactly is stopping us from doing this?

287.text: We have a task. Seven red lines. It's not twenty; it's just seven.

292.text: Anderson, I understand; you're a specialist of a narrow field, you don't see the overall picture.

298.text: But surely it's not a difficult task to draw some seven lines!

303.text: Any fool can criticise, no offence, but you're an expert, you should know better!

310.text: OK. Let me draw you two perfectly perpendicular red lines, --

315.text: and I will draw the rest with transparent ink.

318.text: They'll be invisible, but I'll draw them.

326.text: Yes, but at least a couple with green ink.

328.text: Oh, and I have another question, if I may.

331.text: Can you draw one of the lines in the form of a kitten?

335.text: In the form of a kitten.

336.text: Market research tells our users like cute animals. It'd be really great if --

342.text: Look, I can of course draw you a cat.

345.text: I'm no artist, but I can give it a try.

347.text: But it won't be a line any more. It will be a cat.

349.text: A line and a cat: those are two different things.

351.text: A kitten. Not a cat, but a kitten.

353.text: It's little, cute, cuddly. Cats, on the other hand --

359.text: Anderson, at least hear her out!

361.text: She hasn't even finished speaking, and you're already saying "No!"

364.text: I got the idea, but it is impossible to draw a line in the form of a cat...ten.

375.text: So, where did we stop? What are we doing?

377.text: Seven red lines, two with red ink, two with green ink and the rest - with transparent.

383.text: Excellent! In which case that's everything, right?

386.text: Oh, oh, I almost forgot, we also have a red balloon.

388.text: Do you know if you could inflate it?

394.text: What do I have to do with balloons?

398.text: Anderson, can you or can you not do this? A simple question.

402.text: As such, I can of course, but --

403.text: Excellent. Organise a business trip, we'll cover the expenses, --

407.text: go over to their location, inflate the balloon.

412.text: Well this was very productive, thank you all!

428.text: Can I ask one more question, please?

430.text: When you inflate the balloon, could you do it in the form of a kitten?

437.text: I can do anything, I can do absolutely anything.
